prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for not keeping my husband undisturbed while he works from home.
My husband switched jobs within the past year or so and new job allows him to work from home  a few days a week.  He decided to set up his office in our bedroom.  I suggested he set up in the basement where he would be guaranteed silence and very little disruption.  He prefers to work from our bedroom because the view is better.  His job is 90% conference calls so while he is up there, I have to keep kids from disturbing him which basically means the whole top floor of our house is off limits while he is on calls.  It also means I can’t shower in my bathroom, do chores, put away laundry, or even take a nap when the baby is sleeping.  I also work from home but also take on most of the house chores and dealing with kids.  Him being up there negates my ability to take a damn shower or a poop in peace when I want to.   Since we have adequate space in the basement I told him that we would never bother him while he is down there ever but I can’t promise him silence if he stays in our bedroom. He says i am the asshole for not being quiet when he’s on calls while I think he is the asshole for not setting his office up in the dang basement. Please resolve our fight for us.  Thank you!
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's see. The user is asking if the person who wrote the story is in the wrong. The situation is about the husband setting up his office in the bedroom, causing disruptions for the wife.

First, I need to analyze the key points. The husband works from home a few days a week and chose the bedroom over the basement because of the view. His job is mostly conference calls, so he needs silence. The wife has to manage the kids, chores, and her own work. She can't use the bathroom, do chores, or nap when he's on calls. She suggested the basement for him, but he refused. Now she's saying he's the asshole, but the user thinks she's in the wrong.

Hmm. The husband's choice to set up in the bedroom makes sense because he prefers the view, but it's creating a conflict. The wife is trying to balance her responsibilities. If the basement is available and offers more space, why not use it? The husband's decision affects her ability to manage the household. Maybe the problem is that he didn't consider her needs and the practicality of the basement. 

The wife is being realistic about the basement's advantages—less disruption. But he's prioritizing his comfort. However, she's the one handling most of the domestic tasks and work. It seems like there's a lack of compromise here. The husband might be in the wrong by not choosing the basement, which would help both their situations. The wife is trying to maintain household functions, which are essential. So, the answer might be that the author (the wife) is not in the wrong. She's standing her ground for practical reasons. The husband's preference isn't justifiable when it causes so much disruption. So the answer should be B.
